section.title: Defining relative clauses
section.sectiontitle: Defining relative clauses give us more information about a noun. They answer the questions Which person? Which thing? Which place? Defining relative clauses come immediately after the noun in the main clause.
section.text1a: This is the book which you want.
section.text2a: That is the place where I was born.
section.sectiontitle2: Use who to talk about people, which to talk about things and where to talk about what happens in a place.
section.text3: She's a teacher. I like her.
section.text3a: She's the teacher who I like.
section.text4: That's a shop. I bought my shoes there.
section.text4a: That's the shop where I bought my shoes.

section.title: Defining relative clauses
section.sectiontitle: That can be used instead of who or which.
section.text1: The young man who I work with never stops talking.
section.text1a: The young man that I work with never stops talking.
section.text2: Tom bought the jacket which we saw yesterday.
section.text2a: Tom bought the jacket that we saw yesterday.
section.sectiontitle2: Don't use commas before or after defining relative clauses.
section.text3a: Spinach is the only vegetable which I never eat.
section.text4a: Here's the money which you lent me yesterday.
